<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Total automotive sales</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">23,971</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">26,945</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">44,556</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">$</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">47,831</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="font-size:1px">
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Automotive sales during the three months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $24.0 million, a decrease from $26.9 million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Automotive sales for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted of $19.1 million of vehicle, options and related sales,
and $4.8 million of powertrain component and related sales, compared to $26.9 million of vehicle, options and related sales for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Automotive sales during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $44.6 million, a decrease from $47.8 million during the six months
ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Automotive sales for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted of $37.2 million of vehicle, options and related sales, and $7.3 million of powertrain component and related sales, compared to $47.8 million of
vehicle, options and related sales for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the first three quarters of 2009, we
continued to fulfill reservations for the Tesla Roadster which we began to deliver in 2008, and we had made a significant effort to increase our production capacity in order to accelerate deliveries to customers on our waitlist. As a result, a
significant portion of the revenue recognized during the first two quarters of 2009 came from fulfilling reservations placed prior to 2009. Beginning with the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2009, sales of the Tesla Roadster began more closely
approximating the level of orders placed during the quarter and since that quarter, we have experienced period over period growth in sales. As such, vehicle, options and related sales for the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 were more
reflective of current demand as compared to the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Similarly, zero emission vehicle, or ZEV, credit sales which are included in vehicle, options and related sales, were higher during the three and six
months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 as the fulfillment of a significant number of reservations allowed us to sell a larger number of ZEV credits. The decrease in vehicle deliveries was partially offset by higher selling prices from an expanded offering
of vehicle options to our customers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In February 2010, we began offering a leasing program to qualified customers in the
United States for the Tesla Roadster. Through our wholly owned subsidiary, Tesla Motors Leasing, Inc., qualifying customers are permitted to lease the Tesla Roadster for 36 months, after which time they have the option of either returning the
vehicle to us or purchasing it for a pre-determined residual value. We account for these leasing transactions as operating leases and accordingly, we recognize leasing revenues on a straight-line basis over the term of the individual leases. As of
June 30, 2010, we had deferred revenues of $0.5 million of down payments which will be recognized over the term of the individual leases. Lease revenues are recorded in vehicle, options and related sales within automotive sales revenue and for the
six months ended June 30, 2010, we recognized $0.1 million. During the three months ended June 30, 2010, approximately 23% of the vehicles delivered in the United States during the quarter were under operating leases. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Powertrain component and related sales were comprised primarily of battery packs and chargers that we delivered to supply Daimler&#146;s
Smart fortwo program. We have been selected by Daimler to supply it with up to 1,500 battery packs and chargers to support a trial of the Smart fortwo electric drive in at least five European cities. We began delivering and recognizing revenue for
these production battery packs and chargers at the end of 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">46 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prior to 2010, most of our revenues had been generated through sales of our vehicles in the
United States and we had no revenues from sales outside of the United States prior to the third quarter of 2009. Our international sales commenced with the launch of the Tesla Roadster in Europe in July 2009 and since then, we have recognized
revenue from sales of the Tesla Roadster in additional countries including Canada, Japan and Hong Kong during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. For the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, 60% and 54%, respectively, of our revenue
from vehicle, options and related sales, were derived outside of the United States. All of our powertrain component and related sales were derived outside of the United States. As we continue to expand into additional new markets, we expect our
international revenues to increase in aggregate dollar amounts and to remain relatively consistent as a percentage of total revenues in future periods. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">While revenue related to servicing vehicles has been insignificant to date, we expect such revenues to increase in future periods as we
sell more vehicles and as vehicle warranties begin to expire. Additionally, we expect our development services revenue may fluctuate in future periods based on the timing of cash receipts as compared to the timing of meeting revenue recognition
criteria. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Development Services </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Beginning in the first quarter of 2010, we started entering into development services arrangements with the expectation that our
development services would constitute a viable revenue-generating activity. We began recognizing development services revenue during the first quarter of 2010 with the development and delivery of modular battery packs for Freightliner Custom Chassis
Corporation, or Freightliner, an affiliate of Daimler. These battery packs were to be used in electric delivery vans in a limited number of Freightliner&#146;s customer trials. Prior to 2010, compensation that we had received from our first
development arrangement with Daimler for battery packs and chargers for its Smart fortwo program, was recorded as an offset to research and development expenses. This early arrangement was motivated primarily by the opportunity to engage Daimler and
at the same time, jointly progress our own research and development activities with the associated development compensation. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, Daimler also engaged us to assist with the development and production of a battery
pack and charger for a pilot fleet of its A-Class electric vehicles to be introduced in Europe during 2011. We began providing development services for this program during the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 and had received an aggregate of
$5.5 million in payments; however, as we had not executed a final agreement related to this program as of March&nbsp;31, 2010, we deferred the $5.5&nbsp;million of payments that had been received from Daimler to that point. In May 2010, we executed
a final agreement under which Daimler would make additional payments to us for the successful completion of certain development milestones and the delivery of prototype samples. During the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, we received an
aggregate of $5.0 million in payments and recognized $4.4 million of the total payments received to date in development services revenue. As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, there was accounts receivable of $4.2 million and $7.6 million of deferred revenues
that will be recognized during the remaining term that we expect to complete our development activities under this program. Development services revenue for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was comprised primarily of revenues from the A-Class
development program as well as $0.2 million related to our development services to Freightliner. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We intend to grow our
development services revenue over time by establishing additional commercial arrangements with Daimler, Toyota and other automobile manufacturers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">47 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cost of Revenues and Gross Profit </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cost of revenues during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $22.1 million, a decrease from $24.8&nbsp;million during the three
months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Cost of revenues during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $39.1 million, a decrease from $47.8&nbsp;million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The decrease in cost of revenues for both the
three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was driven primarily by the significant number of vehicles delivered during the first two quarters of 2009 from fulfilling customer reservations placed prior to 2009. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In February 2010, we began offering a leasing program to qualified customers in the United States for the Tesla Roadster. Through our
wholly owned subsidiary, Tesla Motors Leasing, Inc., qualifying customers are permitted to lease the Tesla Roadster for 36 months, after which time they have the option of either returning the vehicle to us or purchasing it for a pre-determined
residual value. We account for these leasing transactions as operating leases and accordingly, we record cost of automotive sales equal to the depreciation of the leased vehicles on a straight-line basis over the term of the individual leases. Cost
of automotive sales related to leased vehicles has not been significant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The decrease in cost of revenues from automotive
sales for these periods was partially offset by the increase in cost of revenues from development services. Cost of development services includes engineering support and testing, direct parts, material and labor costs, manufacturing overhead,
including amortized tooling costs, shipping and logistic costs and other development expenses that we incur in the performance of our services under development agreements. During the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, Daimler engaged us to
assist with the development and production of a battery pack and charger for a pilot fleet of its A-Class electric vehicles to be introduced in Europe during 2011. As of March&nbsp;31, 2010, a development agreement had yet to be finalized and as
such, the related development services costs of $0.5&nbsp;million that we incurred during the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 were expensed in research and development. In May 2010, we finalized the agreement and began recording the costs
related to this program in cost of revenues for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Gross profit for the three months
ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $6.3 million, an increase from $2.1 million for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The increase was driven primarily by an expanded offering of vehicle options to our customers; the continued launch of the Tesla
Roadster internationally, where in certain markets, we have experienced higher average selling prices; lower material cost; and the gross profit contributed by our development services revenues which we began to recognize in 2010. As discussed
above, although we had deferred the recognition of revenues on the Daimler A-Class development program until we had executed a final agreement during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, costs we had incurred for these activities during the
three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 were expensed in research and development in the first quarter. As such, certain of the A-Class development services revenue that we recognized during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, did not have any
corresponding cost of revenues recorded during the quarter, which favorably impacted our gross profit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Gross profit for the
six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $10.1 million, an increase from $55,000 for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The increase was driven primarily by an expanded offering of vehicle options to our customers; the continued launch of the
Tesla Roadster internationally, where in certain markets, we have experienced higher selling prices; cost improvements associated with the model changeover from the Tesla Roadster to the Tesla Roadster 2 during the second half of 2009; and the gross
profit contributed by our development services revenues which we began to recognize in 2010. Similar to the comparison of gross profit for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 with the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009, our gross profit was
favorably impacted by the fact that certain of the A-Class development services revenue that we recognized during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 did not have any corresponding cost of revenues recorded during the period. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We expect our development services revenue may fluctuate in future periods based on the timing of cash receipts as compared to the timing
of meeting revenue recognition criteria. This may cause our gross profit and gross margin to be similarly impacted. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">48 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Research and Development Expenses </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Research and development expenses consist primarily of personnel costs for our teams in engineering and research, supply chain, quality,
manufacturing engineering and manufacturing test organizations, prototyping expense, contract and professional services and amortized equipment expense. Also included in research and development expenses are development services costs that we incur,
if any, prior to the finalization of agreements with our development services customers as reaching a final agreement and revenue recognition is not assured. Development services costs incurred after the finalization of an agreement are recorded in
cost of revenues. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Research and development expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 were $15.4 million, an
increase from $1.9 million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Research and development expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 included $8.5 million in Daimler Smart fortwo development compensation which was recorded
as an offset to research and development expenses. The $13.5&nbsp;million increase in research and development expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted primarily of the $8.5 million Daimler development compensation offset
recognized during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009, and a $4.6&nbsp;million increase in employee compensation expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 primarily associated with significantly higher headcount to support our
Model&nbsp;S and powertrain development activities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Research and development expenses during the six months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2010 were $28.7 million, an increase from $9.9 million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Research and development expenses during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 included $8.5 million in Daimler Smart fortwo
development compensation which was recorded as an offset to research and development expenses. The $18.8&nbsp;million increase in research and development expenses during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted primarily of an
$8.6&nbsp;million increase in employee compensation expenses during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 primarily associated with significantly higher headcount to support our Model&nbsp;S and powertrain development activities, and the $8.5
million Daimler development compensation offset recognized during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the three
months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010, Daimler engaged us to assist with the development and production of a battery pack and charger for a pilot fleet of its A-Class electric vehicles to be introduced in Europe during 2011. As of March&nbsp;31, 2010, a
development agreement had yet to be finalized and as such, the related development services costs of $0.5&nbsp;million that we incurred during the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2010 were expensed in research and development. In May 2010, we
finalized the agreement and began recording the costs associated with this program in cost of revenues for the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Since the commercial launch of the Tesla Roadster, our investment in related research and development has decreased significantly. We
are, however, in the process of significantly increasing our research and development efforts for the Model&nbsp;S, which has resulted in an increase in our research and development expenses in both aggregate dollar amounts and as a percentage of
our revenues. We also anticipate that the additional costs that we will incur in operating our planned Model&nbsp;S manufacturing facility in Fremont, California will further increase these expenditures until the start of production of the
Model&nbsp;S. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">49 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Selling, General and Administrative Expenses </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling, general and administrative expenses consist primarily of personnel and facilities costs related to our Tesla stores, marketing,
sales, executive, finance, human resources, information technology and legal organizations, as well as litigation settlements and fees for professional and contract services. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling, general and administrative expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 were $22.2 million, an increase from $8.2
million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The $14.0&nbsp;million increase in our selling, general and administrative expenses during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted primarily of a $5.5&nbsp;million increase in
stock-based compensation expense related to a larger number of outstanding equity awards, the $2.4 million error correction of additional stock-based compensation expense that should have been recorded during the three months ended December&nbsp;31,
2009 and a higher common stock valuation applied to new grants made subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2009; a $3.7&nbsp;million increase in employee compensation expenses related to higher sales and marketing headcount to support a larger number of stores
in the United States and Europe and higher general and administrative headcount to support the expansion of the business and our efforts of becoming a public company; a $1.2 million increase in professional services costs related to ongoing
trademark and patent work, recruiting, as well as general corporate development activities; and a $1.8&nbsp;million increase in office, information technology and facilities-related costs to support the growth of our business, including the opening
of new stores and our transition to our Palo Alto headquarters. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling, general and administrative expenses during the six
months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 were $38.8 million, an increase from $14.9 million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The $23.9&nbsp;million increase in our selling, general and administrative expenses during the six months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2010 consisted primarily of a $8.5&nbsp;million increase in stock-based compensation expense related to a larger number of outstanding equity awards, a higher common stock valuation applied to new grants made subsequent to
June&nbsp;30, 2009, and the $2.4 million correction of additional stock-based compensation expense that should have been recorded during the three months ended December&nbsp;31, 2009; a $6.8&nbsp;million increase in employee compensation expenses
related to higher sales and marketing headcount to support a larger number of stores in the United States and Europe and higher general and administrative headcount to support the expansion of the business and our efforts of becoming a public
company; a $3.7&nbsp;million increase in office, information technology and facilities-related costs to support the growth of our business, including the opening of new stores and our transition to our Palo Alto headquarters; and a $1.8 million
increase in professional services costs related to ongoing trademark and patent work, recruiting, as well as general corporate development activities. The remainder of the increase was driven primarily by a higher level of marketing activities and
costs to support expanded headcount. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We expect selling, general and administrative expenses to increase both in aggregate
dollar amounts and as a percentage of revenue in future periods as we continue to grow and expand our operations, increase our sales and marketing team to handle our expanding customer base and market presence, and as we meet support the
requirements of being a public company. We also expect an increase in our selling, general and administrative expenses as a result of our planned increase in the number of Tesla stores. As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, we had opened 13 Tesla stores in the
United States and Europe. We plan to open additional stores during 2010. We also anticipate that the additional costs we will incur in operating our planned Model&nbsp;S manufacturing facility in Fremont, California will further increase these
expenditures until the start of production of the Model&nbsp;S. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">50 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Interest Expense </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Interest expense during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $0.5 million, a decrease from $1.1 million during the three months
ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Interest expense during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $0.7 million, a decrease from $2.5 million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The decrease for both the three and six months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2010 was primarily related to our convertible notes which were converted into shares of our Series&nbsp;E convertible preferred stock in May 2009, partially offset by interest expense recognized in 2010 related to our loans under the
DOE Loan Facility. We expect interest expense to increase significantly in aggregate dollar amounts and, prior to the launch of the Model&nbsp;S, as a percentage of revenues, as we continue to draw down on the DOE Loan Facility. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Other Income (Expense), Net </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Other income (expense), net consists primarily of the change in the fair value of our convertible preferred stock warrant liability and
transaction gains and losses on our foreign currency-denominated assets and liabilities. We expect our transaction gains and losses will vary depending upon movements in the underlying exchange rates. We expect the charges resulting from the change
in the fair value of our convertible preferred stock warrant liability, excluding the DOE warrant liability, to be eliminated after July&nbsp;2, 2010, as these warrants will either be net exercised or expire. The DOE convertible preferred stock
warrant became a common stock warrant on July&nbsp;2 and will be carried at its estimated fair value with changes in its fair value reflected in other income (expense), net, until its expiration or vesting. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Other expense, net, during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $6.7 million, an increase in expense compared to other expense,
net, of $1.7 million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Other expense, net, during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $10.0 million, an increase in expense compared to other income, net, of $0.3 million during the six months
ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The increase in expense for both the three and six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was primarily due to the fair value changes in our convertible preferred stock warrant liability as well as the liability related to common
stock warrants to certain of our stockholders which we issued in May 2010, both of which increased significantly in conjunction with the increase in our common stock valuation. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Provision for Income Taxes </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our provision for income taxes during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $9,000, an increase from $8,000 during the three
months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. Our provision for income taxes during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was $0.1 million, an increase from $16,000 during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009. The increase for both the three and six months
ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 was due primarily to the launch of the Tesla Roadster in Europe in July 2009 and the ensuing increase in taxable income in our international jurisdictions in subsequent periods. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Liquidity and Capital Resources </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of June&nbsp;30, 2010, our principal sources of liquidity were our cash and cash equivalents in the amount of $47.3&nbsp;million which
included investments in money market funds. Our primary source of cash historically has been proceeds from the sales of convertible preferred stock, sales of convertible notes, refundable reservation payments from customers for the Tesla Roadster
and more recently from sales of the Tesla Roadster, our compensation for electric powertrain development services and refundable reservation payments for our Model&nbsp;S. Through June&nbsp;30, 2010, we had raised an aggregate of $319.2&nbsp;million
from sales of convertible preferred stock and convertible note financings. Since inception through the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, we had accumulated net operating losses of $328.7 million. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">51 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Initial Public Offering and Toyota Concurrent Private Placement </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;28, 2010, our registration statement on Form S-1 relating to our IPO was declared effective by the SEC. The IPO closed on
July&nbsp;2, 2010, at which time we sold 11,880,600 shares of our common stock and received cash proceeds of $188.8&nbsp;million from this transaction, net of underwriting discounts and commissions. Additionally, we have incurred offering costs of
$4.5 million related to the IPO. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Concurrent with the closing of our IPO, we sold 2,941,176 shares of our common stock to
Toyota in a private placement transaction for aggregate proceeds of $50.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As required under our DOE Loan
Facility, we must set aside 50% of the net proceeds from the IPO and the concurrent Toyota private placement up to a maximum of $100.0 million, to fund a separate, dedicated account. Following the completion of our IPO and concurrent private
placement on July&nbsp;2, 2010, we transferred $100.0 million of the net proceeds from the initial public offering and the concurrent private placement to fund the dedicated account. We will record this cash as restricted cash during the three
months ending September&nbsp;30, 2010. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>DOE Loan Facility </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On January&nbsp;20, 2010, we entered into our DOE Loan Facility for $465.0&nbsp;million to support the expansion of our manufacturing
operations. Up to an aggregate principal amount of $101.2&nbsp;million will be made available under the first term loan facility to finance the build out of a facility to design and manufacture lithium-ion battery packs, electric motors and electric
components, or the Powertrain facility. Up to an aggregate principal amount of $363.9&nbsp;million will be made available under the second term loan facility to finance up to 80% of the costs eligible for funding for the development of, and to build
out the manufacturing facility for, our Model&nbsp;S sedan, or the Model&nbsp;S facility. We have paid for a portion of the 20% of the budgeted costs related to our Model&nbsp;S Facility and therefore expect to receive 91.5% reimbursement from the
DOE Loan Facility for ongoing budgeted costs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our ability to draw down funds under the DOE Loan Facility is conditioned upon
several draw conditions. We are currently in compliance with these draw conditions. For the Powertrain facility, the draw conditions include our achievement of progress milestones relating to the development of the powertrain manufacturing facility
and the successful development of commercial arrangements with third parties for the supply of powertrain components. For the Model&nbsp;S facility, the draw conditions include our achievement of progress milestones relating to the design and
development of the Model&nbsp;S and the planned Model&nbsp;S manufacturing facility, including an environmental assessment of such facility approved by the DOE and the completion of the processes under the National Environmental Policy Act and the
California Enviornmental Quality Act. Certain advances will be subject to additional conditions to draw-down related to the site on which the applicable project is located. We are currently progressing towards our milestones and expect to meet them
in a timely manner. Additionally, the DOE Loan Facility provides for the ability to update milestones should a reasonable need arise. Loans may be requested under the facilities until January 22, 2013, and we have committed to complete the projects
being financed prior to such date. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">52 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Through June&nbsp;30, 2010, we had received loans under the DOE Loan Facility for an
aggregate of $45.4 million with interest rates ranging from 2.5% to 3.4%. In July 2010, we received additional loans under the DOE Loan Facility for $2.1 million at interest rates ranging from 2.1% to 2.6%. Interest on advances under the DOE Loan
Facility is payable quarterly in arrears. Advances under the Powertrain Facility are repayable in 28 equal quarterly installments commencing on December&nbsp;15, 2012 (or for advances made after such date, in 26 equal quarterly installments
commencing on June&nbsp;15, 2013). All outstanding amounts under the Powertrain Facility will be due and payable on the maturity date of September&nbsp;15, 2019. Advances under the Model&nbsp;S Facility are repayable in 40 equal quarterly
installments commencing on December&nbsp;15, 2012 (or for advances made after such date, in 38 equal quarterly installments commencing on June&nbsp;15, 2013). All outstanding amounts under the Model&nbsp;S Facility will be due and payable on the
maturity date of September&nbsp;15, 2022. Advances under the loan facilities may be voluntarily prepaid at any time. All obligations under the DOE Loan Facility are secured by substantially all of our property. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The DOE Loan Facility documents contain customary covenants that include, among others, a requirement that the projects be conducted in
accordance with the business plan for such project, compliance with all requirements of the ATVM Program, and limitations on our and our subsidiaries&#146; ability to incur indebtedness, incur liens, make investments or loans, enter into mergers or
acquisitions, dispose of assets, pay dividends or make distributions on capital stock, pay indebtedness, pay management, advisory or similar fees to affiliates, enter into certain affiliate transactions, enter into new lines of business, and enter
into certain restrictive agreements, in each case subject to customary exceptions. The DOE Loan Facility documents also contain customary financial covenants. We are currently in compliance with these covenants. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The DOE Loan Facility documents also contain customary events of default, subject in some cases to customary cure periods for certain
defaults. In addition, events of default include a failure of Elon Musk, our Chief Executive Officer, Product Architect and Chairman, and certain of his affiliates, at any time prior to one year after we complete the project relating to the
Model&nbsp;S Facility, to own at least 65% of capital stock held by Mr.&nbsp;Musk and such affiliates as of the date of the DOE Loan Facility. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">53 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to our obligation to fund a portion of the project costs as described above, we
have agreed to set aside 50% of the net proceeds from our initial public offering and the concurrent Toyota private placement and any subsequent offerings of stock occurring before the completion of the projects, up to an aggregate of $100 million,
to fund a separate, dedicated account under our DOE Loan Facility. This dedicated account can be used by us to fund any cost overruns for our powertrain and Model&nbsp;S manufacturing facility projects and will also be used as a mechanism to defer
advances under the DOE Loan Facility. This will not affect our ability to draw down the full amount of the DOE loans, but will require us to use the dedicated account to fund certain project costs up front, which costs may then be reimbursed by
loans under the DOE Loan Facility once the dedicated account is depleted, or as part of the final advance for the applicable project. We will be required to deposit a portion of these reimbursements into the dedicated account, in an amount equal to
up to 30% of the remaining project costs for the applicable project and these amounts may similarly be used by us to fund project costs and cost overruns and will similarly be eligible for reimbursement by the drawdown of additional loans under our
DOE Loan Facility once used in full. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For additional information related to our DOE Loan Facility, see Note 7 of our condensed
consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We expect that the proceeds from
our initial public offering, the concurrent Toyota private placement and the loans under the DOE Loan Facility, together with our anticipated cash from operating activities and cash on hand, will be sufficient to fund our operations for the next 24
months. In order to fund our operations beyond that time, we may need to raise additional funds through the issuance of equity, equity-related or debt securities or through obtaining credit from government or financial institutions. This capital
will be necessary to fund our ongoing operations, continue research, development and design efforts, establish sales and service branches, improve infrastructure such as expanded battery assembly facilities, and introduce new vehicles such as the
Model&nbsp;S. We cannot be certain that additional funds will be available to us on favorable terms when required, or at all. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Leasing Activities </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In February 2010, we began offering a leasing program to qualified customers in the United States for the Tesla Roadster. Through our
wholly owned subsidiary Tesla Motors Leasing, Inc., qualifying customers are permitted to lease the Tesla Roadster for 36 months, after which time they have the option of either returning the vehicle to us or purchasing it for a pre-determined
residual value. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">When compared to our sales of vehicles, our leasing activities will spread the cash inflows that we would
otherwise receive upon the sale of a vehicle, over the lease term and final disposition of the leased vehicle. As such, our cash and working capital requirements will be directly impacted and if leasing volume increases significantly, the impact may
be material. However, after taking into consideration our current and planned sources of operating cash, our ability to monitor and prospectively adjust our leasing activity, as well as our intent to collect nonrefundable deposits for leased
vehicles that are manufactured to specification, we do not believe that our planned leasing operations will materially adversely impact our ability to meet our commitments and obligations as they become due. As we will also be exposed to credit risk
related to the timely collection of lease payments from our customers, we intend to utilize our credit approval and ongoing review processes in order to minimize any credit losses that could occur and which could adversely affect our financial
condition and results of operations. We intend to require deposits from customers electing a lease option for vehicles built to a customer&#146;s specifications on the same timeframe and under the same circumstances as from customers purchasing our
vehicles outright. Through June&nbsp;30, 2010, our leasing activity has not had a significant adverse impact on our liquidity. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">54 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Reservation Payments </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A component of our cash flows from operations has been our receipt of reservation payments from our customers. Reservation payments
consist of reservation and membership payments that allow potential customers to hold a reservation for the future purchase of a Tesla Roadster or Model&nbsp;S. For our 2010 model year Tesla Roadsters manufactured to specification, our current
purchase agreement requires the payment of an initial $9,900, &#128;11,500 or &pound;10,000 deposit, depending on the location of the customer. For the Model&nbsp;S, we require an initial reservation payment of at least $5,000. For vehicles
purchased directly from our showrooms, no deposit is required. Prior to the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, our reservation policy was to accept reservation payments from all customers who wished to purchase a Tesla Roadster and require full
payment of the purchase price of the vehicle at the time the customer selected their vehicle specifications. During the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, we changed our policy to require nonrefundable deposits for Tesla Roadsters manufactured
to specification. However, we also occasionally accept reservation payments for the Tesla Roadster if a customer is interested in purchasing a vehicle but not yet prepared to select the vehicle specifications. For customers who have placed a
reservation payment with us, the reservation payment becomes a nonrefundable deposit once the customer has selected the vehicle specifications. We now require full payment of the purchase price of the vehicle only upon delivery of the vehicle to the
customer. We do not believe that these changes will materially impact our liquidity or capital resources. Reservation payments for a vehicle are recorded as a current liability when received. No later than upon the delivery of a vehicle, the
reservation payments collected on a customer&#146;s account are applied against the total purchase price of the vehicle. Reservation payments are expected to fluctuate as the number of reservation holders on the Tesla Roadster reservation list
decreases, while the number of reservation holders on the Model&nbsp;S reservation list increases. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Summary of Cash Flows
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash Flows from
Operating Activities </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We continue to experience negative cash flows from operations as we expand our business and build our
infrastructure both in the United States and internationally. Our cash flows from operating activities are significantly affected by our cash investments to support the growth of our business in areas such as research and development and selling,
general and administrative. Our operating cash flows are also affected by our working capital needs to support growth and fluctuations in inventory, personnel related expenditures, accounts payable and other current assets and liabilities.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net cash used in operating activities was $45.2&nbsp;million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. The largest
component of our cash used during this period related to our net loss of $68.0 million, which included non-cash charges of $9.5&nbsp;million related to stock-based compensation expense, $8.7&nbsp;million related to the fair value change in our
convertible preferred stock warrant liability and $4.6&nbsp;million related to depreciation and amortization. Significant operating cash outflows were primarily related to $67.5&nbsp;million of operating expenses, $39.1&nbsp;million of cost of
revenues, a $6.6&nbsp;million increase in inventory and a $4.5&nbsp;million decrease in our accrued liabilities, partially offset by a $6.0&nbsp;million increase in accounts payable. Inventory increased to meet our production requirements while the
net increase in accounts payable and accrued liabilities was mostly due to the growth of our business. Significant operating cash inflows for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 were derived primarily from sales of the Tesla Roadster and
powertrain components as well as from development services activity. Significant operating cash inflows were comprised primarily of automotive sales of $44.6 million, $4.7&nbsp;million of development services revenue, a $7.6&nbsp;million increase in
deferred revenues, partially offset by a $3.0&nbsp;million increase in accounts receivable. In the first quarter of 2010, Daimler engaged us to assist with the development and production of a battery pack and charger for a pilot fleet of its A-Class
electric vehicles to be introduced in Europe during 2011, and in May 2010, we executed a final agreement under which Daimler would make additional payments to us for the successful completion of certain development milestones and the delivery of
prototype samples, of which we received $4.2 million during the three months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010. The increase in deferred revenues was primarily driven by payments that we had received from Daimler in relation to this development arrangement
for which revenue recognition has yet to be achieved. Deferred revenues also increased from our vehicle leasing activities as we are recognizing the lease down-payments over the term of the operating leases. The increase in accounts receivable was
related primarily to powertrain component sales and development services during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 in relation to Daimler&#146;s Smart fortwo and A-Class programs. During the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010, we received
$5.2&nbsp;million of net new reservation payments for the Model&nbsp;S. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">55 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net cash used in operating activities was $28.3&nbsp;million during the six months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2009. The largest component of our cash used during this period related to our net loss of $26.9 million, which included non-cash charges of $3.1&nbsp;million related to depreciation and amortization and $2.7&nbsp;million related to
interest on convertible notes, as well as a non-cash gain of $1.5&nbsp;million from the extinguishment of convertible notes and warrants. Significant operating cash outflows were primarily related to $47.8&nbsp;million of cost of revenues,
$33.2&nbsp;million of operating expenses, a $8.8&nbsp;million increase in inventory and a $2.1 million increase in prepaid expenses and other current assets, partially offset by a $2.3&nbsp;million increase in accounts payable and a
$0.5&nbsp;million increase in accrued liabilities. Inventory increased to meet our production requirements and the increases in prepaid expenses and other current assets, accounts payable and accrued liabilities were primarily due to the growth in
our business. Significant operating cash inflows for the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 were derived primarily from sales of the Tesla Roadster as well as development compensation related to the Daimler Smart fortwo development arrangement.
Cash inflows related to automotive sales activity were comprised of $47.8 million in revenues and a $4.3&nbsp;million increase in reservation payments, partially offset by a $2.9&nbsp;million decrease in deferred revenues and a $1.2 million increase
in accounts receivable. Reservation payments increased as a result of our efforts to accelerate deliveries to customers on our waitlist and concurrently request additional payments at the time the customer selected their vehicle specifications. Cash
inflows from the Daimler Smart fortwo development arrangement were $4.4&nbsp;million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash Flows from Investing Activities
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We continue to experience negative cash flows from investing activities as we expand our business and build our
infrastructure both in the United States and internationally. Cash flows from investing activities primarily relate to capital expenditures to support our growth in operations as well as restricted cash that we must maintain in relation to facility
lease agreements, equipment financing, and certain vendor credit policies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net cash used in investing activities was
$19.5&nbsp;million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 primarily related to capital purchases of $17.7 million and an increase in restricted cash of $1.8 million. The increase in capital purchases was driven primarily by our transition to
and build out of our powertrain manufacturing facility and corporate headquarters in Palo Alto, California, a $3.4 million deposit paid towards the purchase of manufacturing equipment as well as a non-refundable payment of $3.0 million made to NUMMI
in relation to the purchase of an existing automobile production facility located in Fremont, California which has yet to close. The increase in restricted cash was primarily related to certain refundable reservation payments segregated in
accordance with state consumer protection regulations in Washington State and a deposit paid into escrow for the purchase of manufacturing equipment. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">56 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net cash used in investing activities was $5.0&nbsp;million during the six months ended
June&nbsp;30, 2009 primarily related to purchases of capital equipment of $3.4 million and an increase in restricted cash of $1.6 million. The increase in restricted cash was primarily related to a contractual deposit placed with a vendor as part of
the vendor&#146;s normal credit policies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net cash used in investing activities is expected to increase substantially as we
build out and tool our planned Model&nbsp;S manufacturing facility in Fremont, California, and our powertrain manufacturing facility in Palo Alto, California. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash Flows from Financing Activities </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have financed our operations primarily with proceeds from issuances of convertible preferred stock and convertible notes, which
provided us with aggregate net proceeds of $296.8&nbsp;million on a cumulative basis through December&nbsp;31, 2009, and to a lesser extent and more recently, from loans under the DOE Loan Facility. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cash provided by financing activities was $42.3 million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2010 comprised primarily of $45.4
million we received from our loans under the DOE Loan Facility, partially offset by $3.5 million of issuance costs we incurred in relation to our DOE Loan Facility and our initial public offering. Cash provided by financing activities was $74.8
million during the six months ended June&nbsp;30, 2009 comprised primarily of $49.4 million in net proceeds from the issuance of Series E convertible preferred stock and $25.5&nbsp;million in proceeds received from the issuance of convertible notes
and warrants. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On July&nbsp;2, 2010, we completed our initial public offering, at which time we received cash proceeds of
$188.8&nbsp;million from this transaction, net of underwriting discounts and commissions. Additionally, we have incurred offering costs of $4.5 million related to the IPO. Concurrent with the closing of our IPO, we received proceeds of
$50.0&nbsp;million from our concurrent private placement with Toyota. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Contractual Obligations </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table sets forth, as of June&nbsp;30, 2010 certain significant cash obligations that will affect our future liquidity (in
thousands): </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
